Gold Run | Photograph by Elena Pochesneva

It was like a dream, like a tale which became the reality,” writes #YourShotPhotographer Elena Pochesneva. “The white horseese living in Camargue Natural Park are really so beautiful, so free.”

Lay Up | Photograph by Babis Beslemes (@cbeslemes)

"My daughter Zoe and I went to a near basketball court to play. While looking up to get the ball I noticed some interesting shapes and lines," writes #YourShotPhotographer Babis Beslemes. Top Shot: A Different Perspective | Photograph by Megan Lorenz (@mlorenzphotography)
.
#YourShotPhotographer Megan Lorenz made this sweet portrait of a Burrowing owlet in Florida. She writes, “An owl’s eyes are large in order to improve their efficiency, especially under low light conditions. Their eyes are actually elongated tubes which are held in place by bony structures in the skull called Sclerotic Rings. For this reason, an owl cannot move its eyes and can only look straight ahead. The owl more than makes up for this by being able to turn its head up to 270 degrees left or right from the forward-facing position and almost upside down.” This photo was selected for the Daily Dozen on June 28, 2019.

.
“In December 2018, an extremely unique opportunity was given to a small group of skydivers to jump over the Great Pyramids of Giza.
